comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: The Sydney Harbour Bridge was opened on this day, 19 March 1932

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Wow, what a crowd. Usually its such a quiet place. I'd love a larger version to examine the faces in the crowd. And are they the funnels of a ship in the distance? Here are two more of the same scene by Sam Hood: 1 & 2 and one by Harold Cazneaux If you look carefully the same cars are parked along the road.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Thanks pellethepoet. Those are great comparison views.

I'm thinking there was a vantage point provided for the photographers, indeed I suppose there was more than one.

I think if we look around we will be able to find a photograph of the photogs on this perch, taking these photos.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Apologies BobMeade if I didn't give you any time to look around yourself, but I think I've found the vantage point: 1, 2 & 3 Here's another closer to the bridge (you may have noticed Cazneaux's photo was from a slightly different vantage point, further to the right): 1 & 2. These two seem to have been taken from the first vantage point. And so do these newsreels: 1 & 2. Notice the photographer running towards the camera 1:37-1:41.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Outstanding work pellethepoet, thank you very much.


Those are all great views which aptly convey the sense of occasion.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
We've replaced this with a larger image. Hope it helps with those faces. 

It must have been a hot day - I can see a couple of women shading themselves with newspapers on their heads.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: that ship in the right background is parked at a rather odd location.  seems to be the end of east balmain.
